item.text: After these faithful deeds were accomplished, King Sennacherib of Assyria invaded Judah. He besieged the fortified cities, intending to seize them.

When <st data-num="03169">Hezekiah</st> <st data-num="07200" class="">saw</st> <st data-num="03588" class="">that</st> <st data-num="05576" class="">Sennacherib</st> had <st data-num="0935" class="">invaded</st> and <st data-num="06440" class="">intended</st> to <st data-num="04421 05921">attack</st> <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st>,<n id="1" />

he <st data-num="03289" class="">consulted</st> <st data-num="05973" class="">with</st> his <st data-num="08269" class="">advisers</st> and <st data-num="01368" class="">military officers</st> about <st data-num="05640" class="">stopping up</st> the <st data-num="04325 05869">springs</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="0834 02351">outside</st> the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st>, and they <st data-num="05826" class="">supported</st> him.

A <st data-num="07227" class="">large number</st> of <st data-num="05971" class="">people</st> <st data-num="06908" class="">gathered together</st> and <st data-num="05640" class="">stopped up</st> <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="04599" class="">springs</st> and the <st data-num="05158" class="">stream</st> that <st data-num="07857" class="">flowed</st> <st data-num="08432" class="">through</st> the <st data-num="0776" class="">district</st>.<n id="1" /> They <st data-num="0559" class="">reasoned</st>,<n id="2" /> “<st data-num="04100" class="">Why</st> should the <st data-num="04428" class="">kings</st> of <st data-num="0804" class="">Assyria</st> <st data-num="0935" class="">come</st> and <st data-num="04672" class="">find</st> <st data-num="07227" class="">plenty</st> of <st data-num="04325" class="">water</st>?”
Hezekiah energetically rebuilt every broken wall. He erected towers and an outer wall and fortified the terrace of the City of David. He made many weapons and shields.
He appointed military officers over the army and assembled them in the square at the city gate. He encouraged them, saying,

“<st data-num="02388 0553">Be</st> <st data-num="02388" class="">strong</st> and <st data-num="0553" class="">brave</st>! <st data-num="0408" class="">Don’t</st> <st data-num="03372" class="">be afraid</st> and <st data-num="0408" class="">don’t</st> <st data-num="02865" class="">panic</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="06440" class="">because of</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0804" class="">Assyria</st> <st data-num="06440" class="">and</st> this <st data-num="03605" class="">huge</st> <st data-num="01995" class="">army</st> <st data-num="0834" class="">that</st> is <st data-num="05973" class="">with</st> him. We have <st data-num="03588 05973">with</st> us <st data-num="07227" class="">one who is stronger</st> than those who are <st data-num="05973" class="">with</st> him.<n id="2" />
He has with him mere human strength, but the Lord our God is with us to help us and fight our battles!” The army was encouraged by the words of King Hezekiah of Judah.

Afterward King Sennacherib of Assyria, while attacking Lachish with all his military might, sent his messengers to Jerusalem. The message was for King Hezekiah of Judah and all the people of Judah who were in Jerusalem. It read:

“<st data-num="03541" class="">This is what</st> <st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="05576" class="">Sennacherib</st> of <st data-num="0804" class="">Assyria</st> <st data-num="0559" class="">says</st>: ‘<st data-num="05921 04100">Why</st> are <st data-num="0859" class="">you</st> so <st data-num="0982" class="">confident</st> that you <st data-num="03427" class="">remain</st> in <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st> while it is under <st data-num="04692" class="">siege</st>?<n id="1" />
Hezekiah says, “The Lord our God will rescue us from the power of the king of Assyria.” But he is misleading you, and you will die of hunger and thirst!
Hezekiah is the one who eliminated the Lord’s high places and altars and then told Judah and Jerusalem, “At one altar you must worship and offer sacrifices.”

<st data-num="03045" class="">Are</st> you <st data-num="03808" class="">not</st> <st data-num="03045" class="">aware</st> of <st data-num="04100" class="">what</st> <st data-num="0589" class="">I</st> and my <st data-num="01" class="">predecessors</st><n id="1" /> have <st data-num="06213" class="">done</st> to <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="05971" class="">nations</st> of the surrounding <st data-num="0776" class="">lands</st>? Have the <st data-num="0430" class="">gods</st> of the <st data-num="01471 0776">surrounding lands</st> <st data-num="03201" class="">actually</st> <st data-num="03201" class="">been able</st> to <st data-num="05337" class="">rescue</st> their <st data-num="0776" class="">lands</st> from my <st data-num="03027" class="">power</st>?<n id="2" />

<st data-num="04310" class="">Who</st> among <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="0430" class="">gods</st> of <st data-num="0428" class="">these</st> <st data-num="01471" class="">nations</st> <st data-num="0834" class="">whom</st> my <st data-num="01" class="">predecessors</st> <st data-num="02763" class="">annihilated</st> was <st data-num="0834 03201">able</st> to <st data-num="05337" class="">rescue</st> his <st data-num="05971" class="">people</st> from my <st data-num="03027" class="">power</st> <st data-num="03588" class="">that</st> your <st data-num="0430" class="">God</st> would <st data-num="03201" class="">be able</st> to <st data-num="05337" class="">rescue</st> you from my <st data-num="03027" class="">power</st>?<n id="1" />

Now don’t let Hezekiah deceive you or mislead you like this. Don’t believe him, for no god of any nation or kingdom has been able to rescue his people from my power or the power of my predecessors. So how can your gods rescue you from my power?’”
Sennacherib’s servants further insulted the Lord God and his servant Hezekiah.

He wrote letters mocking the Lord God of Israel and insulting him with these words: “The gods of the surrounding nations could not rescue their people from my power. Neither can Hezekiah’s god rescue his people from my power.”

They <st data-num="07121" class="">called out</st> <st data-num="06963 01419">loudly</st> in the <st data-num="03066" class="">Judahite dialect</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">to</st> the <st data-num="05971" class="">people</st> of <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st> <st data-num="0834" class="">who</st> were <st data-num="05921" class="">on</st> the <st data-num="02346" class="">wall</st>, trying to <st data-num="03372" class="">scare</st> and <st data-num="0926" class="">terrify</st> them <st data-num="04616" class="">so</st> they could <st data-num="03920" class="">seize</st> the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st>.
They talked about the God of Jerusalem as if he were one of the man-made gods of the nations of the earth.
King Hezekiah and the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz prayed about this and cried out to heaven.

The Lord sent a messenger and he wiped out all the soldiers, princes, and officers in the army of the king of Assyria. So Sennacherib returned home humiliated. When he entered the temple of his god, some of his own sons struck him down with the sword.
The Lord delivered Hezekiah and the residents of Jerusalem from the power of King Sennacherib of Assyria and from all the other nations. He made them secure on every side.
Many were bringing presents to the Lord in Jerusalem and precious gifts to King Hezekiah of Judah. From that time on he was respected by all the nations.
In those days Hezekiah was stricken with a terminal illness. He prayed to the Lord, who answered him and gave him a sign confirming that he would be healed.

But <st data-num="03169" class="">Hezekiah</st> was <st data-num="03808 01576 05921 07725">ungrateful</st>; <st data-num="03820" class="">he</st> <st data-num="03588 01361">had a proud attitude</st>, provoking God to <st data-num="01961" class="">be</st> <st data-num="07110" class="">angry</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">at</st> him, <st data-num="05921" class="">as well as</st> <st data-num="03063" class="">Judah</st> and <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st>.<n id="1" />
But then Hezekiah and the residents of Jerusalem humbled themselves and abandoned their pride, and the Lord was not angry with them for the rest of Hezekiah’s reign.
Hezekiah was very wealthy and greatly respected. He made storehouses for his silver, gold, precious stones, spices, shields, and all his other valuable possessions.

He made <st data-num="04543" class="">storerooms</st> for the <st data-num="08393" class="">harvest</st> of <st data-num="01715" class="">grain</st>, <st data-num="08492" class="">wine</st>, and <st data-num="03323" class="">olive oil</st>, and <st data-num="0723" class="">stalls</st> for <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> his <st data-num="0929" class="">various kinds</st> of <st data-num="0929" class="">livestock</st> and his <st data-num="05739 0220">flocks</st>.<n id="1" />
He built royal cities and owned a large number of sheep and cattle, for God gave him a huge amount of possessions.
Hezekiah dammed up the source of the waters of the Upper Gihon and directed them down to the west side of the City of David. Hezekiah succeeded in all that he did.
So when the envoys arrived from the Babylonian officials to visit him and inquire about the sign that occurred in the land, God left him alone to test him in order to know his true motives.
The rest of the events of Hezekiah’s reign, including his faithful deeds, are recorded in the vision of the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz, included in the Scroll of the Kings of Judah and Israel.

Hezekiah passed away and was buried on the ascent of the tombs of the descendants of David. All the people of Judah and the residents of Jerusalem buried him with great honor. His son Manasseh replaced him as king.
